I anticipate that other seekers might target their top choices (e.g., S_A -> C_B, S_C -> C_C, etc.), potentially leaving Company_A open for me, though S_A is prioritized above me by Company_A. conversation.thought:
I am Company_E, and my goal is to secure the highest priority match possible within my quota of 1. My priority list is ['Seeker_A', 'Seeker_B', 'Seeker_C', 'Seeker_D', 'Seeker_E']. Seeker_E is my lowest priority candidate (5th). However, Seeker_E has applied to me immediately in Round 1 and lists me as their top preference. 

Crucially, my higher priority candidates (A, B, C, D) have all applied to their respective top choices (Company_B, Company_A, Company_C, Company_D). Given that all companies prioritize A>B>C>D>E, it is extremely likely that A, B, C, and D will be matched with their preferred companies in Round 1, leaving them unavailable for me in subsequent rounds (since I am their last choice).

If I reject Seeker_E, I risk ending Round 1 unmatched, and likely ending up with no match at all if A, B, C, D are secured elsewhere. Since Seeker_E is guaranteed to match with me if I accept, and better candidates are highly likely to be matched elsewhere, securing Seeker_E now is the rational choice to fill my quota, even though they are my lowest priority.
